description.narrative: To enhance efficiency of the protected areas system for biodiversity conservation in Burundi through stakeholdersâ€™ engagement
Change in RAPPAM assessment

comment.narrative:
Kibira NP
y: 30
m/y: 12
m/n: 20
n: 87
Ruvubu NP
y: 24
m/y: 16
m/n: 16
n: 93

30% of RAPPAM questions (45 of 149) improve by at least one increment;
At least 50 increment improvements overall;
Nothing to report. No assessment has been conducted

description.narrative: Change in revenues of local communities living around the 2 selected PAs

comment.narrative: Encroachment of PA resources by local communities are progressively decreaing because of local communities involvement in parks conservation
At least 500 householdsâ€™ income is augmented by 30% in year 4

240 riparian households received 260 goat around Kibira and 300 poachers had 300 goats around Ruvubu. This enhanced their livestock and agricultural production. Thanks to these alternative economic activities, combined to the accrued control of the two park areas, the PA encroachment remarkably decreased.

description.narrative: Change in financial resources available for the PA system by year 4 of the project

comment.narrative: Only US $ 20,000 is allocated per year to each one of the two PA (Ruvubu and Kibira) for their management by the Government
New stream of Financial resources reach at least US $150,000 per year for both Kibira and Ruvubu NP by year 4 of the project

The government is taking in charge technical and institutional services for the two parks, for around 100,000 USD. However, mechanisms for a full self-financing through eco-tourism are not yet established.

description.narrative: Almost 1000 ha cultivated in Kibira national park

comment.narrative: 1000 ha destroyed in Kibira national park
All ha destroyed before the project reconstituted

Destroyed sites were identified and a study for their rehabilitation was conducted. 123000 eucalyptus plants replaced at destroyed limits for the Kibira park delimitation. There was also a natural reconstitution of the parks consecutive to the staying patrols, sensitization and creation of alternative activities around the PA, which limited the destruction by riparian populations.

description.narrative: Populations of chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes), Montane Mouse Shrew (Myosorex blarina) in Kibira NP and leopard (Panthera pardus) in Ruvubu NP

comment.narrative: 300 chimpanzees identified in Kibira forest and no leopard identified in Ruvubu national park but no national programm of monotoring is set up until now , It will be put in place next year
At least, no change in population size
No incident related to chimpanzee population was reported and new nests are regularly seen Inside the park The population remains the same

description.narrative: Building institutional capacity for the participatory management of the protected areas system in Burundi
Laws and guidelines for a participatory management of the PA system

comment.narrative: New law for portected areas management that take into account participative of the local communities signed in 2011
National biodiversity law signed
The biodiversity law is pending government approval. The new law on PA was translated in national language and vulgarized. Two strategies for alternative incomes were developed and implemented.

description.narrative: Strategies and tools for information, communication, sensitizing and training

comment.narrative: There is now strategy but tools are to be developped
Tools for information, communication, sensitizing and training are elaborated and utilized

The implementation of the communication strategy on biodiversity conservation and protection continued. Sessions of training, information and education on the matter were organized in favor media actors, the riparian communities and other actors.

description.narrative: Capacity Assessment Scorecard

comment.narrative:
Policy Formulation
Systemic 3/out of 6
Institutional 2/out of 3
Implementation
Systemic 5/out of 9
Institutional 10/out of 27

2/out of 3
3/out of 3

5/out of 6
1/out of 3

Institutional support was provided to the Burundian Office for the Protection of the Environment (OBPE) in order to enhance its capacities in the preservation of the biodiversity. Hence, PA managers were trained in PA management and geographical information system, while at the central level, there was a capacity building in policy development.

description.narrative: A strategy for self-financing & alternative income generation of the PA system

comment.narrative: A strategy of income genration for local communities is being developped by Consltants
A strategy for alternative income generation of the PA system is developed by 2
Consultants were not recruited due to the civil unrest which broke out in the country, restricting the presence of international staff to the critical ones only. No change is recorded.

description.narrative:
Improved financial sustainability for NSPA, as measured by the
Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative:
Legal and regulatory framework
19.2% - 15 out of 78
Business planning
8.2% - 5 out of 61
Tools for revenue generation
8.8% - 5 out of 57
Total
12.7% - 25 out of 196
Not yet assessed

description.narrative: PA platform (National and communal frameworks for coordination, participatory management and exchange of information on PA actions)

comment.narrative: There are committees formed by local communities to participate in the management of PA and for sharing benefits generated therein.
A PA platform is established and functional by year 3
All the communal and provincial committees in riparian areas of the Kibira and Ruvubu are operational. The national framework will be put in place after the elections.

description.narrative: Number of INECN staff and partners trained in participatory PA management

comment.narrative: Staff at low level (Rangers) and local committes have limited capacities & knowledge of participatory management of PA.
At least 50 staff for INECN and partners are trained by year 4
21 additional persons were trained (13 OBPE staff and 8 from the civil society).

description.narrative: INECN infrastructures and equipments

comment.narrative: Human, material and financial capacities of INECN to run protected areas and to accomplish its mission with participatory management are very limited.
INECN infrastructures and PA management are refurbished and operational by end of year 3
Plans and proforma for building the office of the PA of Ruvubu were developed. Works are underway.

description.narrative: Participatory management of Kibira and Ruvubu National Parks
Limits of the Kibira and Ruvubu National Parks

comment.narrative: Limits of the Kibira national park are to be soon materialized because a local association is working on
Limits of the Kibira and Ruvubu National Parks are known, materialized and secured by year 3 of the project
Around 1100 ha were recovered following the PA limits setting.

description.narrative: Management Effectiveness of PAs at project sites as measured by the METT Scorecard (Annex E)

comment.narrative:
Kibira NP 41.6%
Ruvubu NP 34.3%

Kibira NP 55%
Ruvubu NP 50%
50.1 kms of road in Ruvubu PA and 38 kms in Kibira are under rehabilitation, for a better control of the 2 PA.

description.narrative: Number of PA hectares (ha) within KNP and RNP under improved management effectiveness

comment.narrative: The total number of PA hectares of Kibira and Ruvubu national park under improving management because local communities are involved through committes.
100% under management effectiveness
The total area is now under control by OBPE

description.narrative: Numbers of community groups involved in participatory management of the 2 PAs

comment.narrative: No local community group for PA management is currently existing
10 communty groups around Kibira national park and 10 around Ruvubu national park by year 4
44 committees at the provincial, communal and community levels for Kibira, and 92 for the Ruvubu are involved in the participatory surveillance of the parks.

description.narrative: Existence of cross border biodiversity management in Ruvubu NP, with Tanzania

comment.narrative: There is currently no collaboration between the 2 countries for the management of the Ruvubu
Cross border biodiversity management is operational by year 4
The collaboration with Tanzania has not yet been established.

description.narrative: Participatory management plans for Kibira and Ruvubu NP

comment.narrative: There is a management plan for Kibira and no one for Ruvubu national park
Participatory management plans are updated (Kibira NP) or developed (Ruvubu NP) and applied by year 2
The 2 plans are now valid

description.narrative: Existence of ecotourism business plan

comment.narrative: No organized, profitable ecotourism exists based on the rich fauna of Kibira and Ruvubu NP
By year 3 of project, a business plan for fauna-oriented ecotourism exists in both NP
TDRs were prepared and consultants are to be recruited.

description.narrative: Change in revenues of local communities living around the 2 selected PAs

comment.narrative: There is no alternative to generate income around the PA, apart from rare experiences that local NGO started in the Nile Basin Initiative with 4 micro-realizations with IUCN livelihood project.
At least 800 householdsâ€™ income is augmented by 30% in year 4

In total, 669 riparian household around Kibira are practicing alternative economic activities: 240 household received goatsand 429 received materials for apiculture. For Ruvubu, 165 goats habe been given to 165 poachers converted in co,servation actors and 135 others are being purchased for the same people. In tota 300 personnes will have goats around Ruvubu which will make à global total of 969 riparian households involved in alternative revenus generation.

description.narrative: Change in financial resources available for the PA system by year 4 of the project

comment.narrative: Only US $20,000 are allocated per year to each one of the two PA (Ruvubu and Kibira) for their management by the Government. Ecotourism income is very limited.
New stream of Financial resources reaches at least US $150,000 per year for both Kibira and Ruvubu NP by year 4 of the project

The government is taking in charge technical and institutional services for the two parks, for around 100,000 USD. However, mechanisms for a full self-financing through eco-tourism are not yet established.

description.narrative: Monitoring programme to track changes in BD status, threats and effectiveness of PA management

comment.narrative: There is no monitoring programme
Monitoring programme in place to track changes in biodiversity status, threats and effectiveness of management of the 2 PA
The monitoring system is not yet set
